awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Aspects of Riemannian Geometry and Manifolds with Density
awd_abstract_narration:
Riemannian geometry investigates the generalization of familiar geometric notions such as length, angle, and volume to more abstract, often high-dimensional, spaces called manifolds. Manifolds and their geometric properties are not only central to various branches of mathematics but also are ubiquitous as mathematical models in the sciences. Perhaps the greatest example of this is in general relativity, where one of Einstein's great breakthroughs was the discovery that gravity is modeled by the mathematical notion of curvature. This research project focuses on curvature of Riemannian manifolds.  Specific emphasis will be placed on manifolds with density, which can be envisioned as Riemannian manifolds composed of a material with variable, as opposed to uniform, density.  Despite the appearance of manifolds with density in various areas of mathematics and applications, including proof of the Poincare conjecture, they are not yet well understood. This project addresses this gap by helping to develop a geometric theory of manifolds with density.  The project also uses geometry as a theme for a coherent program of educational activities that include: (1) professional development workshops in teaching and learning for in-service secondary education teachers, which will help support teachers in transition to recently developed K-12 standards; (2) innovation in introductory differential geometry curricula at the undergraduate and graduate level that, by emphasizing applications, will also foster new interaction between mathematics and science researchers; and (3) training of mathematics graduate students in best strategies for engaging students in introductory calculus courses.
 
Ricci curvature for manifolds with density has been an active area of recent research.  This includes Ricci solitons, which are both fixed points of the Ricci flow and examples of spaces with constant weighted Ricci curvature, and the study of weighted Ricci curvature bounds. The investigator will continue study of the classification of shrinking Ricci solitons in dimension four and higher.  In addition to playing a key role in development of monotonic functionals for the Ricci flow, weighted Ricci curvature bounds also appear in the theory of optimal transport, isoperimetric inequalities, and general relativity and cosmology.   Despite the vast amount of research in Ricci curvature of manifolds with density, there was no corresponding theory of weighted sectional curvature until recently; another goal of this project is to further develop the theory of weighted sectional curvature bounds, including investigating applications and connections to other areas of mathematics.  Recent collaborative work of the investigator also introduces a new geometric approach to manifolds with density that places a certain torsion free affine connection as the fundamental object of study.   This approach not only provides new insight into the weighted Ricci and sectional curvatures but also suggests new natural structures that promise novel results, such as a weighted holonomy group, which will be investigated.

por.por_cntn:
This project is in the field of Riemannian geometry, which investigates the generalization of familiar geometric notions such as length, angle, and volume to more abstract high-dimensional, spaces called manifolds. Manifolds and their geometric properties are not only central to various branches of mathematics but also are ubiquitous as mathematical models in the sciences. This research project has focused on curvature of Riemannian manifolds with density, which can be envisioned as Riemannian manifolds composed of a material with variable, as opposed to uniform, density.

In this project the PI and his collaborators and PhD students have studied several aspects of manifolds with density. 

One research direction has been the study of solitons to curvature flows, which are self-similar solutions to certain systems of geometric PDE. Solitons for curvature flows are important because they describe the geometric fixed points of the flow.  The main thrust of the work in this direction has been the generalization of earlier results of the PI and his collaborators from the Ricci flow to other flows. In 2022, Petersen and the PI generalized their results for gradient homogeneous solitons to the Ricci flow to a general rigidity structure theorem.  This theorem was subsequently used by two of the PI?s PhD students in their PhD theses to study solitons for flows that have been studied elsewhere in the literature.  Erin Griffin applied the theorem to the ambient obstruction and Bach flow, which is an important flow in conformal geometry.  Nicholas Ng studied the case of solitons to the closed G2 Laplacian flow, which is a flow introduced by Bryant as a method to study G2 holonomy metrics.

Another research direction has been the study of near horizon geometries and extremal black holes through their connection to m-Quasi Einstein metrics, something the PI had studied in earlier work.   In 2019 the PI published a paper with Eric Woolgar and Marcus Khuri on this topic that constrained the topology of horizon cross-sections for extreme stationary vacuum black holes through a generalization of the classical splitting theorem from Riemannian geometry.  Subsequently, this motivated one of the PI?s PhD students, Alice Lim, to classify locally homogeneous m-Quasi Einstein metrics in her PhD thesis.  In 2023, the PI also published a manuscript on this topic showing that compact static near-horizon geometries with negative cosmological constant are either Einstein or the product of a circle and an Einstein metric. This is the optimal rigidity result in this case that corrected some earlier statements in the literature.

The third main research direction has been the study of curvature bounds for manifolds with density.  In 2018, the PI, with Kennard and Yeroshkin, expanded their earlier work on the notion of weighted sectional curvature bounds for manifolds with density and introduced a new notion of convexity for these spaces, generalizing several classical theorems from Riemannian geometry to this setting such as Preismann?s theorem and the Cheeger compactness theorem. PhD student Alice Lim also extended in her thesis results about the homology of non-compact manifolds with non-negative Ricci curvature to the weighted setting.

The broader impacts of this project have primarily involved the education of students at the PI?s home institution.  As explained above the thesis research of three PhD students was funded by the award.  These were the PI?s first PhD students. In addition, the PI has recruited three other PhD students who are in their 3rd and 4th years of study in the program towards their degree.   In addition, the PI has taught classes for mathematics and students in other mathematical sciences on curvature at his home institution and innovated in the curriculum to include more applications of curvature to the sciences in introductory differential geometry classes.  While these materials are only in lecture note form at the moment, the PI plans to develop them into a manuscript in the future.  The other broader impact has been professional development for PhD students in the PIs home department as the PI ran a ?job application boot camp? that helped prepare students going on the academic job market.
